program codeforces_469_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, p, q, i, j, temp, count
    integer, allocatable :: X(:), Y(:), combined(:)
    logical :: found

children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Combine X and Y into combined array
    allocate(combined(p + q))
    combined(1:p) = X
    combined(p+1:p+q) = Y

    count = 0 do i = 1, n
        found = .false. do j = 1, p+q
            if (combined(j) == i) then
                found = .true. exit
            end if
        end do
        if (found) then
            count = count + 1
        else
            exit  ! No need to check further if one is missing
        end if
    end do

    if (count == n) then
        print *, "I become the guy."
    else
        print *, "Oh, my keyboard!"
    end if

    deallocate(X)
    deallocate(Y)
    deallocate(combined)
end program codeforces_469_A

tree.original_reasoning:
Okay, I need to translate this Java code to Fortran. Let me start by understanding what the Java code does. 

The program reads input to determine if a player can pass all levels of a game. The first input is n, the total number of levels. Then, there's a list of levels passed by the first guy, followed by levels passed by the second guy. The code checks if all levels from 1 to n are covered by either of the two lists. If yes, it outputs "I become the guy.", else "Oh, my keyboard!".

Let me break down the Java code step by step.

First, it reads n, then the number of levels for the first player (levels). It reads those levels into an array arr. Then it reads the number of levels for the second player (level2), and combines both arrays into arr2. Then, it creates arr3 which is an array from 1 to n. It checks if every element in arr3 is present in arr2. If all are present, count equals n, and it prints the success message.

So, the main steps are: read the inputs, combine the two players' levels, check if all 1..n are present.

Now, translating this to Fortran. Let's note that Fortran has different syntax for loops, arrays, and input handling.

First, in Fortran, we'll need to read the input. The Java code uses Scanner, which in Fortran can be done with READ statements. 

Variables: n, levels (let's call it p), level2 (q), then arrays for the levels. Wait, in Java, arr is the first array (size p), then arr2 is the combination of arr and the second array (size q), so arr2 has size p+q.

But in the code, after reading p levels into arr, then reading q levels into the rest of arr2. So arr2 is the concatenation of the two.

Then, arr3 is an array from 1 to n. Then, for each element in arr3, check if it exists in arr2. If all are found, count equals n.

So, in Fortran:

Read n, then p, read p integers into an array. Then read q, then read q integers. Combine them into a single array (arr2). Then check if all numbers 1 to n are present in arr2.

Wait, but the Java code reads the first array, then appends the second array to it. So arr2 is p + q elements long.

But in the Java code, when building arr2, the first loop copies arr into arr2[0..p-1], then the next loop reads q elements into arr2[p..p+q-1]. Then, for checking, the code iterates through each element of arr3 (1 to n), and for each, checks if it's present in arr2. If yes, increment count and break.

So in Fortran, perhaps we can combine the two arrays into one, then for each number from 1 to n, check if it's in the combined array.

But how to handle dynamic arrays in Fortran? Because p and q are read at runtime. In Fortran, you can use allocatable arrays. But maybe the maximum possible size is manageable. Wait, the problem probably has constraints, but assuming that n can be up to 1e5 or similar, but let's proceed.

Alternatively, read all the elements from both players into a single array. Let's see:

In Java:

After reading p and the first array, then q is read, and the second array is read into arr2 starting from index p. So arr2 is of size p + q.

In Fortran, perhaps we can read p, read p elements into an array, read q, read q elements into another array, then combine them into one array. Then check if all 1..n are in that array.

Alternatively, perhaps process the inputs without combining arrays. Like, read all elements from both players, then check each number from 1 to n against all elements.

But the Java code combines them into arr2 first. Let's replicate that.

So steps in Fortran:

1. Read n.

2. Read p, then read p integers into array X.

3. Read q, then read q integers into array Y.

4. Combine X and Y into a single array arr2 (size p + q).

5. Create an array arr3 with values 1 to n.

6. For each element in arr3, check if it exists in arr2. If all exist, output success.

But perhaps, instead of creating arr3, just loop from 1 to n and check each in arr2.

Yes, that's more efficient. Because arr3 is just 1..n. So in Fortran, for i from 1 to n, check if i is present in arr2. If all are present, output "I become...".

This approach simplifies the code. So perhaps the Java code is more complicated than necessary, but the logic can be optimized.

So in Fortran:

Read n.

Read p, then read p numbers into array X.

Read q, then read q numbers into array Y.

Combine X and Y into a combined array (size p + q).

Then, for each level from 1 to n, check if it's present in the combined array.

If all are present, output success, else failure.

So the key steps are:

- Read all the input numbers.

- Check each 1..n exists in the combined list.

Now, how to implement this in Fortran.

First, variables:

integer :: n, p, q, i, j, temp, count=0

integer, allocatable :: X(:), Y(:), combined(:)

logical :: found

Read n.

Read p.

Allocate X(p)

Read p integers into X.

Read q.

Allocate Y(q)

Read q integers into Y.

Combine X and Y into combined.

Allocate combined(p+q).

combined(1:p) = X

combined(p+1:p+q) = Y

Then, for each i from 1 to n:

Check if i is present in combined.

If any i is missing, then output failure.

Else, output success.

So the code would look like:

program codeforces_469_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, p, q, i, j, temp, count
    integer, allocatable :: X(:), Y(:), combined(:)
    logical :: found

    ! Read input
    read(*,*) n
    read(*,*) p
    allocate(X(p))
    read(*,*) X
    read(*,*) q
    allocate(Y(q))
    read(*,*) Y

    ! Combine X and Y into combined array
    allocate(combined(p + q))
    combined(1:p) = X
    combined(p+1:p+q) = Y

    count = 0
    do i = 1, n
        found = .false.
        do j = 1, p+q
            if (combined(j) == i) then
                found = .true.
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (found) then
            count = count + 1
        else
            exit  ! No need to check further if one is missing
        end if
    end do

    if (count == n) then
        print *, "I become the guy."
    else
        print *, "Oh, my keyboard!"
    end if

    deallocate(X)
    deallocate(Y)
    deallocate(combined)
end program codeforces_469_A
